references: as the models for our experiments(federated learning is frequently utilized in edge scenarios, implying a typical avoidance of models characterized by an excessively large number of parameters.). We utilize the transformers

library from Huggingface for model deployment. We primarily conduct experiments on three types of NLP tasks: text classification, named entity recognition, and question answering. Specifically, for the task of text classification, we utilized the 20Newsgroups
datasets. For the named entity recognition task, we use the WNUT2017
datasets. Lastly, for the question answering task, we implemente the SQuADv1.1
datasets. More detailed information about the dataset and some parameter settings related to federated learning are listed in
. It should be emphasized that we consider extreme non-IID data. Therefore, when we partition the dataset for the clients, we adopt as small
as possible, provided that it doesn‚Äôt significantly affect data heterogeneity or impede the convergence of all methods.

Our method and baselines alike follow some identical training settings. The local training batch is set to 16, the number of regional training epochs is 1, and the local learning rate is chosen from [
] to achieve the best performance. Max sequence length is set to 64 for SemEval-2010Task8, WNUT2017, and PLONER, 256 for 20Newsgroup, 384 for SQuADv1.1 and 512 for MRQA. For FedLR and FeDeRA, rank

references: Using the proposed method and baselines, we evaluate the fine-tuning performance of RoBERTa-base and DeBERTaV3-base. The testing tasks include two text classification tasks, two named entity recognition tasks, and two question answering tasks. For each dataset, we compile the test results across varying communication rounds, enabling a performance comparison while simultaneously observing the convergence speed of different methods. All subsequent tests are conducted under five distinct random seeds and reported the average results.
The text classification task results are displayed in

. FeDeRA consistently surpasses FedLR in performance across different models, datasets, and communication rounds, and it excels over all baselines except for FedFT. FeDeRA is able to achieve performance that is close to or even exceeds that of FedFT. In those results where there is still a gap with FedFT, the margin is extremely minimal. Simultaneously, we have observed that FedFT possesses the fastest convergence rate, achieving higher accuracy with fewer communication rounds. FeDeRA also demonstrates a quicker convergence rate among the remaining baselines, especially in comparison to FedLR. This phenomenon is more pronounced in the experiments with DeBERTav3-base.
The results of the named entity recognition task are presented in

. FeDeRA continues to perform admirably amongst numerous baselines, closely matching or surpassing the performance achievable by FedFT. Moreover, FeDeRA continues to maintain a quicker rate of convergence.
The results of the question answering task are summarized in

. FeDeRA exhibits the same superior performance as in the previous two tasks. FedBF demonstrates a very poor performance, which we speculate is due to the high difficulty of the question answering task and the insufficient trainable parameters of BitFit to learn this task effectively. Conversely, FedAP and FedLR have managed to close the gap with FeDeRA. This is likely because it is more challenging to construct heterogeneously divided data from the question answering dataset compared to the previous two datasets.

references: We also conduct experiments to validate the efficiency of our proposed method in actual federated learning scenarios, thereby demonstrating that FeDeRA can simultaneously balance the optimization of PEFT for both training and communication, whilst ensuring final performance. We employ actual edge devices, Jetson AGX Orin, as clients, and a server with 8

64-Core AMD EPYC 7763 CPU. To simulate a realistic communication context, we implement actual campus WiFi for inter-device communication, offering a bandwidth consistently ranging between 20-30 Mbps. We conduct experiments on the 20Newsgroup, SemEval2010-Task8, and WNUT2017 datasets using RoBERTa and DeBERTaV3. For each task, we designate a target accuracy. We separately document the time required for different methods to reach 90%, 95%, and 99% of this target accuracy. Furthermore, we note the time overheads at different stages of federated learning during the experiment in
for a more effective comparison of the superiority of various methods. It can be observed from

that FedFT consumes more time than other methods in both local training and communication, particularly the cost of communication is considerably higher than other methods incorporating PEFT. This remains the reason why, even if FedFT converges faster and can achieve better performance, we still have to consider the potential of PEFT in federated learning. Even though FeDeRA introduces additional SVD time, this time cost is not high and only needs to be performed once during the entire training process, which is almost negligible compared to the full training time.

records the time for complete federated learning to reach the corresponding accuracy. FeDeRA achieves the shortest training time under all conditions compared to other methods, demonstrating its efficiency while also having superior performance. For RoBERTa, compared to FedFT, FeDeRA reduces the training time by 95.9%, 97.9%, and 96.9%. respectively on three datasets (only comparing 99% target accuracy), while for DeBERTaV3, it achieves 97.3%, 96.5% and 96.5%.

S5.T6.caption: Table 6: In genuine federated learning experiments under different method settings, the time required to achieve 90%, 95%, and 99% of respective target metrics was measured. For the 20Newsgroup and SemEval2010-Task8, the target accuracy was set at 80%, whereas for WNUT2017, the target F1 score was set at 0.5. - indicates that the target accuracy cannot be achieved under the current settings. The unit of measurement for time was hours.

references: We defined a specific number of classes for each dataset to facilitate the partition of the datasets.The following are the detailed information.

The 20Newsgroups dataset comprises around 18000 newsgroups posts on 20 topics and the topics cover a range of subjects from politics to religion to sports to science. The 20 Newsgroups dataset is employed for text classification tasks; consequently, its original labels are utilized as its classes.

SemEval2010-Task8 is aimed at addressing the challenge of Multi-Way Classification of Semantic Relations Between Pairs of Nominals. The task involves identifying and categorizing the semantic relations between specific pairs of nominals within given sentences. It delineates nine distinct types of semantic relations, with each relation type being subject to inversion, thereby totaling 19 potential labels when including an additional ‚ÄôOther‚Äô category for relations that do not conform to any of the predefined types. We also utilize the original labels as classes.

The WNUT2017 dataset refers to the data collection used for the Workshop on Noisy User-generated Text (WNUT) in its 2017 edition. This workshop series focuses on processing and understanding noisy user-generated text, often encountered in social media, online forums, and other web sources. WNUT2017 specifically aimed to address several key tasks in noisy text processing. One of the primary tasks was Named Entity Recognition (NER), which involved identifying and classifying proper names within text into predefined categories such as persons, organizations, locations, etc. The token labels comprise seven parts of speech, further divided into begin and intermediate positions, along with an additional category that does not belong to any of the aforementioned parts of speech, totaling thirteen labels in all. We observe that each training sample may comprise a unique set of token labels, thereby contributing to the learning capability across diverse token labels. Consequently, we catalogue the total types of token labels encompassed within each training sample as its class, as detailed in

PLONER, the abbreviation for Person, Location, Organization Named Entity Recognition, aims to assess the cross-domain generalization capability. It involves selecting samples from representative datasets that include at least one of the three entity types: person, location, and organization. The representative datasets encompass CoNLL2003, OntoNotes 5.O, and WNUT2016. The English data of CoNLL2003 is a collection of news wire articles from the Reuters Corpus. The data for WNUT2016 were primarily collected from Twitter. The OntoNotes5.0 corpus is categorized into several types, which include newswire (News), broadcast news (BN), broadcast conversation (BC), telephone conversation (Tele), and web data (Web). The corpora across various themes inherently exhibit heterogeneity. Hence, while adopting the methodology used for class construction in WNUT2017, we also take into account the source dataset of the samples for further distinction, details are shown in

SQuADv1.1 is a question-answering dataset released by Stanford University. The dataset comprises an extensive collection of question-and-answer pairs, with the questions formulated based on paragraphs from Wikipedia articles, and the answers are extracted directly from these respective passages. SQuADv1.1 does not annotate any tags pertinent to the questions, hence, we employ k-means to generate classes for all training samples directly. The number of clusters chosen for this study is 30.

The MRQA dataset emphasizes the generalizability of question-answering tasks. This dataset is an amalgamation of subsets from 18 existing QA datasets, carefully curated and transformed into the format as SQuAD. Of these 18 datasets, six are designated for training, another six for development, and the final six are reserved for testing purposes. In our approach, we simply employ the source datasets as the classes.

SQuADv1.1 is a question-answering dataset released by Stanford University. The dataset comprises an extensive collection of question-and-answer pairs, with the questions formulated based on paragraphs from Wikipedia articles, and the answers are extracted directly from these respective passages. SQuADv1.1 does not annotate any tags pertinent to the questions, hence, we employ k-means to generate classes for all training samples directly. The number of clusters chosen for this study is 30.

The MRQA dataset emphasizes the generalizability of question-answering tasks. This dataset is an amalgamation of subsets from 18 existing QA datasets, carefully curated and transformed into the format as SQuAD. Of these 18 datasets, six are designated for training, another six for development, and the final six are reserved for testing purposes. In our approach, we simply employ the source datasets as the classes.
